captions.text:
Neutrinos are tiny, almost weightless particles
that only interact via gravity and nuclear

decay. Because they don't interact electromagnetically,
that is, with light, they literally can't

In fact, detecting a neutrino is kind of like
trying to catch a bullet with a butterfly

net – a beam of neutrinos will travel through
lead for two years before it stops. (in comparison,

radiation from nuclear fallout can be blocked
by about ten cm of lead)

So how do you detect a neutrino? One common
way is to fill a big tank with water: we know

light slows down through water, and if a neutrino
with enough energy happens to knock into an

electron, the electron will zip through the
water faster than the light does! When this

happens, the electron gives off a weak glow
called Cherenkov Radiation - it's kind of

like a sonic boom for light, and it allows
us to detect the neutrino. The biggest neutrino

detector in the world is a balloon over the
south pole that actually uses the whole antarctic
ice sheet as its tank of water!

Neutrinos also tell us that the universe is
not the same as its mirror image. If you switch

left with right, clockwise with counterclockwise,
almost all of physics, like gravity, electromagnetism,

and the strong nuclear force, is unchanged.
However, the weird thing about neutrinos is

that in physics terms, they're all left-handed
- their mirror image doesn't exist! So neutrinos

comments.text: How does the neutrino knock an electron if it has no charge﻿
comments.author: Ahmed Medhat

comments.text:
+Ahmed Medhat Well since the Neutrino only interacts with the Weak Force 
and Gravity, that must mean it uses one of those two. And since Gravity is 
dependent on mass and the Electron and Neutrino are hilariously tiny, that 
leaves the Weak Force. The Weak force is divided into W and Z bosons, the W 
is further divided into +W and -W, which can affect the Flavour, and the Z 
which carries Momentum. So in summary, a Neutrino knocks an Electron by 
getting close enough to exchange a Z boson and transfer momentum, thus 
energy. Does that help?
comments.author: Brandon Lokison

comments.text:

charge-less light photons knocks out the electron.

pair is no different than the starting pair.

comments.author: SlewedQuasar8900

comments.text:
+SlewedQuasar8900 As an object approaches the 'true' speed of light, its 
unhindered speed, its mass increases infinitely (at a rate that increases 
as we get closer to the speed of light). Also, perceived time approaches 0 
as speed approaches c (speed of light). Therefore, even though an electron 
is extremely light, as it approaches the speed of light, it would need an 
infinite force for an infinite time to actually reach and pass the speed of 
light. While we can produce the infinite force because the force of gravity 
increases with mass, we can't do anything about the fact that the object 
will eventually reach whatever is causing the gravitational 'pull'.
Sorry for the rant, I'm not sure how to explain this in a shorter or more 
understandable method.
tl;dr  We can never make the electron actually reach the true speed of 
light, just the slowed down speed of light in the water.

comments.author: Maximilian Lotz (Official TinA-LotZ)

comments.text:
+CoBon I know bro :) Thanks for trying to explain, not sure I explained my 
problem well enough. Figured it out though, I may as well explain it. Light 
is an electromagnetic wave, I'm sure you understand that. When light 
travels through water or glass for example, the electromagnetic wave 
produces a varying electromagnetic field. This field affects the particles 
in the material ie. making them produce their own varying electromagnetic 
fields. This varying field is what slows the light down. If light "bounced" 
off particles as you were suggesting, the light would have a chance to do 
weird things from that collision, internal reflection when it isn't 
expected to, however, as we know that doesn't occur. Hope this clears it up!
comments.author: kiklosers1

comments.text:
+kiklosers1 Photons behave both as a particle, and as a weave. We can 
understand refraction better if if we consider the photon a weave when 
studying refraction.
comments.author: CoBon

comments.text:
+CoBon wouldn't this lead to light bending out of it's predicted path? I'm 
aware of refraction, however, if it was bouncing between molecules there 
would be a chance the photon would come out at a "weird" angle (ie. away 
from the path of refraction)
comments.author: kiklosers1

comments.text:
The easy answer is that light slows down in water.
It's a common misconception that light itself slows down in water, what we 
mean when we say that light moves slower in water, is that light (in a way) 
"bounces" between the water molecules, which makes the photons themselves 
travel for a longer amount of time. (Approximately .3x longer in water)
This also explains how light can appear to "speed up" again immediately 
after leaving water into air.
comments.author: CoBon

comments.text:
Like Adam said,  The electron will not go faster than C, but will go faster 
than the heavily slowed down light in the water.

comments.text:
Hello again, I know I promised to keep it short and simple but I wanted to 
demonstrate some good examples. Reading this may actually slow time, 
lol...(Example A.) My old friend Professor Vernon Graham, the late-great 
Mathematician, though not a professor of Physics by trade, you still need 
to complete his courses to become one. Explained to me while comparing Bach 
to Godel,as I was teaching him Bach theory. In one of his many theorems, 
anything can be explained with simple math equations, (Simple for him 
perhaps,) He showed me that light was not a constant, C, but a variable and 
does not = time. The physical laws apply to general relativity as a model, 
but rather time (physically observed by the human eye), closing speed of 2v 
> c. Example, Times moves much faster at Disney-Land and slows down when 
sitting through a boring lecture, “Time fly’s when having fun.” But the 
properties of light can be governed the elements of matter. So traveling 
faster than light, which is not always going to be C = which is 299,792,458 
m/s (in a vacuum). slowing or accelerating light, or other particles, will 
not alter time. 
(Example B.) My awesome friend, Physics Professor and Cosmologist, João 
Magueijo. “The key to finding something is knowing how to look for it.” 
 Author of “Faster than the speed of light” In his book he demonstrates How 
and Why the commonly accepted model of relativity is wrong because many 
factors are overlooked to produce theory of special relativity. He says, 
"The neutrino's been the bad boy of physics and, basically, putting 
physicists out of their comfort zone. A lot of unusual things have been 
revealed by the neutrino." Check out his lectures, his accent is heavy but 
his knowledge is immense… as well as entertaining. 
 (Example C)  (Conversations about Science with Theoretical Physicist Matt 
Strassler) Thousands of trillions of neutrinos passed through several 
neutrino detectors on earth, and of these a tiny handful — about two dozen 
— hit something on their way through.  These collisions were recorded over 
a period of about 13 seconds. No one was paying particular attention at the 
moment that this occurred, but after the supernova was noticed, 
experimental physicists went back and found this flurry of neutrino 
collisions in their data.  The flurry occurred about 20 hours before the 
first observation of the unexpected star in the Large Magellanic Cloud. 
 This discovery represented the birth of neutrino astronomy, now an active 
field of research.  Meanwhile, a look back at older photographs revealed 
one showing visible light from the supernova that was taken only 3 hours 
after the neutrinos had arrived on earth. Since the shock wave from the 
supernova blast had to make its way out of the exploding star before the 
debris could begin to shine, whereas the neutrinos from the explosion could 
sail right through the star unimpeded, a delay of a few hours between the 
arrival of the neutrinos and the arrival of the light was expected.
(References) Fernando Ferroni, president of the Italian Institute for 
Nuclear Physics.  Phil Bouchard / PHPRO Inner & Outer Gravitational Time 
Dilation Factors vs. Radius, CERN.  João Magueijo, Imperial College, 
London.  Professor Vernon Graham, Hartford University.  
Anyway, without boring you with anymore of my long-ass articles, Ill just 
leave it at that. Check'em out and have a good week. TTYL
comments.author: Ted Cabana

comments.text: +Ted Cabana thanks you too I'll look at it right now online.
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
Oh no, don't mute my post, Ill be terrible upset! 8^(. Just when I thought 
we were developing a meaningful relationship. I think I did answer your 
questions, but even better, I coaxed you into seeking the knowledge that 
you desperately desire. So I doubt you'll mute my posts. I gave you my 
personal email, If you honestly and sincerely wish to learn more. Than 
contact me privately. And read my book, that's my final condition. 
Otherwise, its late on my end of the world and I'm going to bed. Oh, and if 
you ever get the chance to look through a good telescope. Point your eyes 
toward Messier 87. That's another project for you. You'll see two distinct 
jets of light, Its quite beautiful. The white light is produced by photon 
particles moving at the speed of light, naturally. The blue light is 
produced by Muon Neutrino's, moving 6-X'S faster than the speed of light, 
as recorded by Hubble. But I think that's only approximate. If you truly 
are open to new theories, as you claim, than look in the directions I give 
you. Anyway, for more information you'll have to wait until Monday. I'll be 
quite busy til then. Good night, and have a good weekend.
comments.author: Ted Cabana

comments.text:

comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
I have not insulted you, its just my course sense of humor you take out of 
context, stop being such a baby about it for Christ sake. You obviously you 
are not open to new theories as you so demonstrated by your refusal to 
understand what I presented. I made you a considerable offer  and you 
refused because you simply wish to uphold you sophomoric attitude in front 
of you little audience. Like I said, I write as a ghost writer for some of 
the greatest scientific minds of our time, they come to me for my 
perception in the art of writing. But divulging their names would go 
against my code of ethics, which they confide in me. But if you wish to 
discus this in private, outside of an audience, I will happily give you 
references, and share information that will freak you right the fuck out. 
But you chose the route of trying your hardest to disrespect and discredit 
me so therefor I retract my offer. I thought you had potential but I now 
realize that you are only perusing this conversation to establish yourself 
as a grand know-it all. Swallow your pride kid and stop acting like a punk. 
I have interviewed scientists from Kaiser Wilhelm Society to cold war 
physicists who worked of top secret military operations all around the 
world. I have sat and discussed things with people you only read about in 
sci-fi magazines. I try to share my knowledge with young aspiring 
scientists who I feel have potential of carrying out their work, I thought 
you had that potential. But I was wrong, your just a smart ass punk trying 
to impress your friends. I am a collector of knowledge, I don't have long 
to live in this world and I intend to share certain things with people I 
feel are worthy. You disappointed me. I still think you have that 
potential, but your skepticism is all to common for a kid your age. 
Remember that things are not always as they appear, and don't believe 
everything you read, and your future will be unlimited. Or you can just 
insult me and think of me as some old fool who knows not what I say. But 
that's totally your lose. There are many others Id rather discuss the 
secrets of life with. I cant understand how you could let your immense ego 
interfere with reality, its frightening to think of you as someones teacher 
some day. Its like arguing with a 3 year old, you explain where to poop 
goes when you flush the toilet but it just freaks them out and they keep 
asking why? why? over and over again. Its redundant. So consider this 
conversation over, you simply refuse to step outside of your bubble.  And 
that's sad. And please don't take it personally, Its just the way you are 
for now, and I'm shore that you will change as you grow older and wiser and 
realize that not only does life itself change, but science and theorems 
change as well because we are constantly learning new things and developing 
the technology to discover the truth about what we thought we new. It is 
absolute ignorance that I have no tolerance for, I'm not calling you 
ignorant, so don't get defensive. In fact I'd rather extend an olive branch 
by referring to you as a very bright you man, with the potential to become 
someone great, someday, but just not now. I know this message is long, but 
as I said before, I love to write, which is why people seek me out to write 
theists and essays and articles for them because I can make it a little 
more interesting. Which makes them look better. Perhaps you would someday 
utilize my services, if you could only develop a more serious attitude 
toward your contributions. In my line of work I get to meet the most 
incredible people, I would never disrespect them to try and make myself 
look superior in front of others, that would be absolutely incomprehensible 
by any standard. You currently lack the maturity to consent to my 
explanation of things, but perhaps you may read about it tomorrow in one of 
many journals of medicine and/or science. And then you'll say that its true 
because you read it in a scientific news print. And though my true name may 
not be associated with it, due to the fact I write under pen names, 
depending on the subject, as most authors do, you will finally see the 
light. I can not continue these discussions any more with you because its 
becoming redundant, you ask me a question, I give you an answer, and you 
re-ask the same question. Its tiring.  I've said all that I can and I hope 
that it soon sinks into your resilient bubble. I'm not tying to present my 
self as a super intellect, only a vesicle or clear voice for those who are. 
So anyway, as this conversation began, as I recall, read my latest novel 
Manner of the Sundog, and embrace it. I think you will enjoy it. It may 
take some time to perceive but I have enlightened you, contrary to your 
next reply, and I will smile when I see that in you. Good Luck with your 
future, and don't take drugs. They will fuck you up.
comments.author: Ted Cabana

comments.text:
Your reply is just what I said to you. You asked me where I get my 
information and I told you, but you seemed apprehensive of my answer. Then 
you accused me of having a superiority complex, Doctor, but that is 
perceptively how you exemplify yourself. I explained what you wanted to 
know, but to refused to absorb the obvious. I thought that maybe you were 
some sort of professor or expert in the field of particle physics, which is 
why I offered to do an article on you for a reputable paper, but I was 
wrong, as you so pointed out. Why do you refuse to believe the facts? Sorry 
if I seamed a bit rambunctious with your line of questioning, but as I 
said, I write for real scientists. They not only explain what they've 
learned but they also show me so I can document clear and precise evidence 
of their discoveries. You however have shown me what I suspected all along. 
An egotistical geek with a "Sheldon" complex, trying to gather a following 
on you tube discussions for the sake of promoting yourself as a superior 
expert on certain subjects, but you folded on that. What I do for a living 
brings me into the den of genius's, I was hoping you would be such by the 
way you argued with me for several months over a simple fact,, which I am 
correct on. I wish you were old enough to understand the live experience 
trumps text book knowledge because that's where it comes from. My only 
desire is to share that with aspiring scientists, but I learned that you 
tube and Google is not the place to do that, because there is always some 
wanna-be know-it-all who has to challenge what is real with his presumed 
assumption of what he/she learned somewhere in a high school classroom. As 
you said if previous conversation, you are no expert, neither am I, but I 
have learned from experts with first hand knowledge. I am only trying to 
educate people with the latest innovations and discoveries of science, 
medicine, paleontology and politics. That is what I have spent decades 
doing. And why the experts call on me to write about their theories and 
discovery of scientifically proven facts. You however are just trying from 
all sorts of angles to somehow discredit me, for shits and giggles. But as 
I said, and this is a fact. If you are indeed serious about learning what 
many others cant even fathom, than please go back and re-read what I told 
you, investigate for yourself before replying with some juvenile smart ass 
antidote. Because in the long run, you'll only discredit your self. I only 
write and teach what is fact, and the idea of some you tube blogging smart 
ass who has to get the last word to appease his own superiority complex is 
beyond comprehension. I've seen the fact, the data, the research results 
and watched them repeated before my own eyes, and what I saw was real. I 
thought it impossible myself at first but I was amazed at seeing it with my 
own eyes. As you will too some day. Now I wish not to continue this mundane 
argument with someone who refuses to believe the truth. Its like arguing 
evolution with the creationist religious fanatics. I'm only gonna say it 
once more for the intelligent people. Despite what you have learned in you 
out dated high school text books. There is a new speed king in town, and it 
is called a neutrino. Please indulge yourself in the applications of 
quantum physics to understand this. (That ONE guy excluded). who continues 
to hold onto early 19th century ideology of outdated science. And refuses 
to believe the earth is round, or the earth orbits the sun. Now I know your 
just gonna ask again, where did I get my facts? why do I think I'm so 
superior in my knowledge?  But I have told you already, but its not that 
you don't understand, its that you don't wanna admit that you understand. 
The future grestly depends on the learning of new information in order to 
proceed with a higher understanding of how the universe works and what more 
we can understand. I hope the young minds of this generation will 
comprehend the idea that science is not written in stone, but we learn new 
things everyday. And I will try to keep you informed, regardless of what 
some ego-eccentric sanctimonious kid, who refuses to keep up with modern 
science has to say.
comments.author: Ted Cabana

comments.text:
+Ted Cabana tell me how you know. Stop with the "I have watched it happen 
but you just learn from books." Fine, then tell me how it works. I told you 
how it works according to modern accepted theories, now tell me the Ted 
theory.
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
Like I said, some day you'll discover that you are wrong. I thought you 
could do better but I guess I was wrong about that. Too bad. In the future 
when you realize I was correct, you'll be able to look back and remember 
where you first learned it. But don't let me bring you down, keep studying, 
someday you'll see beyond your cocky persona.
Neutrino's kick the shit out of light, and I watched them do it.  But like 
you said, "You'r no expert".
comments.author: Ted Cabana

comments.text:
+Ted Cabana If anyone has a superiority complex it's you. I asked you a 
simple question and you got very defensive. I have some background in 
quantum mechanics, multivariable calculus, a little tensor analysis, and 
some general relativity, but I am by no means an expert on any of it. I 
asked you where you got your information and why you thought that so that 
you could walk me through it and we could have a conversation about it but 
you're not in the mood for that apparently. Neutrinos do have a mass, which 
is why they can not move faster than the speed of light. I have no clue 
where you heard otherwise but that's a simple fact. Neutrinos can move 
faster than light in a specific medium, yes. This is because of when the 
beam of light enters the medium it can be said that it is carried by a 
polariton instead of a photon, and this polariton causes the light itself 
to travel slower in the medium. A neutrino will not interact with the 
medium very much, and therefor travel though the medium faster than the 
polariton, producing Cherenkov radiation. this does not however mean that 
the neutron is moving faster than light does in a vacuum. In the sun, 
nuclear fusion occurs in the core which creates light and neutrinos. these 
neutrinos do not interact with matter very much and reach Earth in just a 
few minutes. The light emitted at the same time as the neutrino interacts 
with the matter, and therefore takes longer to reach the surface of the Sun 
but once there they propagate at the speed of light. I feel like those are 
the two things you are confusing for neutrinos being able to propagate at 
and past the speed of light. If you're ever interested in learning some 
factual information just let me know and I'd be happy to walk you through 
it. Maybe one day you could stop acting like you're smarter than everybody 
because you believe in pseudoscience and you could teach someone something 
factual.﻿ And stop asking people to email you.
comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
Look, I know your trying to develop a following on you tube or Google or 
whatever and the last thing you want is to get burned by some journalist 
science writer. I couldn't care less about that, I'm not about followings, 
I'm about promoting an intellectual future. In a few years from now you'll 
reflect back and see how obstinately you reacted to learning something new. 
I want you to study what I wrote and perhaps develop a better understanding 
of it. Perhaps even write an award winning research paper or book about it. 
I'm not looking for credit or anything, I have enough of that, but I am 
always looking to promote and develop the education of young scientists. I 
write, that's what I do, If you could show me what you have revealed in 
your studies, I can help you turn it into literature. All I'd want in 
return is the satisfaction of helping you achieve the status of a ground 
breaking scientist. You can converse with me through my g-mail address. 
Tedcabana@gmail. You never know, it could make you rich or famous, or both. 
Its up to you. Just show me what you have, and nothing plagiarized, and 
I'll do the rest.
comments.author: Ted Cabana

comments.text:
Want to learn about my neutrino theory? 
  Check out my new novel Manner of the Sundog, a geopolitical Sci-Fi 
thriller about a young physicist living in a postmodern Antarctica. The 
story portrays life, culture and the political struggles following a 
century of intense climate change, war and social discord. Young physics 
prodigy, Bane Elrick, is thrown into a conflict between the Annortic's 
governing body, ICS, and an imperialistic union controlled by GRANT corp. 
an aggressive multinational resource and trade company. The story is set 
around the city of Ellsworth, located on the beautiful west coast of 
Antarctica, where ICS has become the target of espionage and the victim of 
brutal attacks carried out by Grant's Lynx army in an attempt to recover 
land rights and lost secrets of intangible technological powers. Bane 
Elrick tells his story of life, love, and excessive greed, and his rise to 
leadership of the world’s most elusive continent and sovereign 
nation…Antarctica. ﻿

comments.text:
This is a very trivial and unsatisfactory discussion of the neutrino. There 
is no discussion whatever of the importance of the neutrino in nuclear 
theory, and of the triumph of its theoretical prediction by the brilliant 
theoretical physicist Wolfgang Pauli to explain the energy spectrum of beta 
decay. Here, we get silliness about the "Vampires of Physics." Some of the 
Minutephysics pieces are pretty good, but some of them really suck.  ﻿

when light travels through a medium with particles in it, such as water or 
air, its speed is not reduced. All that occurs is that the light takes 
longer to get from one point to another because its interacting with 
different particles. Take for example, you are walking through and empty 
room at 3mp/h, and it takes u 5 seconds to walk through the room, if the 
room is not filled with people, even if you walk through the same room at 
3mp/h, you need to change your root to avoid bumping people, so your path 
is different and not a straight line. This means that it will take longer 
for you to cross the room. It does not mean that your speed has changed, 
all it means is that you take a longer route

The problem with saying this is that the "light speed limit" applies to 
light's speed *in vacuum*.  Through a medium, light's speed is reduced, 
allowing charged particles to move faster than light can--in that medium.

comments.text:
+MajorMarlfox Not exactly. "Light travels at a constant speed no matter 
what"
is a conclusion discovered before Einstein even started doing physics. What 
Einstein said, is that light travelling at a constant speed *implies* that 
nothing can go faster than light. His theory further explained other 
phenomena he predicted should appear (time dilation, length contraction, 
etc)

+Alied Pérez Martínez Anti neutrinos have been proven to exist (many 
nuclear reactors produce them, in the billions, each second) The original 
detection of a neutrino by the tanks of cadmium chloride solution was 
actually the detection of an antineutrino. I think that this has been known 
by the scientific community for over 20 years (correct me if i am wrong). A 
really good book to start with would be Frank Close's The New Cosmic Onion, 
although it does not have all the concepts right because it is rather old, 
it is a good foundation for education in particle physics, I myself picked 
it up for a read and ended up getting hooked :)

What exists are either left-handed neutrinos or right-handed

anti-neutrinos.
comments.author: gogerychwyrndrobwll

comments.text:
+icecream meanwhile i investigated some more and it turns out that what i 
said earlier doesn't really make sense because in other particles you can 
have left and right handed versions. However, the reason why the neutrino 
is always left-handed is because they always travel very close to the speed 
of light. An electron travelling at that speed will also *always* be 
left-handed. So it is not like the neutrinos are vampires, they're just 
really fast.

Here are my sources, if you're interested.
http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/particles/neutrino3.html
http://www.physicsforums.com/showthread.php?t=594866
comments.author: 3snoW

electrons all have negative charges, there's no elementary particle 
counterpart or "positive electron" unless you are talking about 
positrons... Oh no! Someone call a quantum exorcist, we've got a 
Schrodinger's vampire on our hands!

in water, light bounces around a ton, so getting form point a to b takes 
longer. electrons won't do that, they will take a more direct route, 
getting from point a to b faster than the light. the electron won't

comments.author: thejuicyhamburger

comments.text:
The speed of a a light photon is constant in a vacuum where there is 
nothing in its way that it will bump into. Light as it passed through air 
in our atmosphere is slightly slower than that of light in a vacuum because 
molecules in the air bump into the photons. In water, there are more 
densely populated particles for the photon to become refracted (slowed down 
as it passes through a different medium). The speed of the photon doesn't 
change, but the total time that the photon takes to pass through the water 
does because it's obstructed. 

The electron will move faster because the photons are being refracted.

most massive elementary particles. Remember that the fundamental particles 
can also be looked at as excitation of a quantum field.
comments.author: Nate Jones

comments.text:
If your definition of a fundamental particle is one that is irreducible 
into component particles, then yes, a neutrino(the standard electron 
neutrino which most people refer to when they say a neutrino) is most 
likely a fundamental particle as it is too close to mass-less to possibly 
be made from other particles, but yet again, there are different types of 
neutrinos(muon, tau...), which gives rise to the possibility that they are 
made from different substructures.

comments.author: Jarrett Blair

comments.text:
In water, photons refract off the many densely populated particles, whereas 
an electron will be able to move straight through them. The electron is not 
going faster than the speed of light in a vacuum, but it is making distance 
faster than the photon, which is constantly being refracted by the water's 
molecules. This electron is moving faster than a photon which is moving 
below the speed of light in a vacuum, which is thought to be the fastest 
speed achievable.

comments.text:
You learned something right - nothing travels faster than the speed of 
light in VACUUM! The speed of light in vacuum is the constant c, 
approximately 300,000 km/s. But when light travels through a medium - not 
vacuum - it slows down a lot. And, as the video says, electrons are able to 
travel faster than light in water, but still, the electrons don't travel 
anything near the speed of light in vacuum. Hopefully that clears things up.
